front: When did Rommel arrive in North Africa?
back: February 12, 1941, at Tripoli, Libya

front: What was the nickname given to Rommel?
back: The Desert Fox (Der Wustenfuchs)

front: What was the Afrika Korps?
back: The Deutsches Afrikakorps (DAK) - the German expeditionary force in North Africa commanded by Rommel

front: What medal did Rommel receive in World War I?
back: The Pour le Merite (Blue Max) - Imperial Germany's highest military decoration

front: What was the 'Ghost Division'?
back: Rommel's 7th Panzer Division during the 1940 France campaign - moved so fast even German HQ lost track of it

front: When did Italy invade Egypt?
back: September 13, 1940

front: What was Operation Compass?
back: The British offensive in December 1940 that destroyed the Italian Tenth Army and captured 130,000 prisoners

front: Why was the Suez Canal strategically important?
back: It connected the Mediterranean to the Red Sea, vital for British communications with India and the Far East

front: What was Operation Torch?
back: The Allied invasion of French North Africa (Morocco and Algeria) on November 8, 1942

front: When did the North African Campaign end?
back: May 13, 1943, with the surrender of 275,000 Axis troops in Tunisia

front: How long did the Siege of Tobruk last?
back: 241 days (April 10 to December 7, 1941)

front: Who were the 'Rats of Tobruk'?
back: The Australian and Allied defenders of Tobruk who adopted a German propaganda insult as a badge of honor

front: What was the Gazala Line?
back: A 50-mile defensive line of fortified 'boxes' and minefields built by the British in early 1942

front: Who commanded the Eighth Army at El Alamein?
back: General Bernard Montgomery

front: When was the Second Battle of El Alamein?
back: October 23 to November 11, 1942

front: What was the Qattara Depression?
back: A vast salt marsh and sand sea south of El Alamein, impassable to vehicles, which forced armies to fight on the narrow coastal strip

front: Who founded the SAS?
back: Captain David Stirling, in July 1941

front: What was the original name of the SAS?
back: L Detachment, Special Air Service Brigade - named to deceive German intelligence

front: What was a Lewes Bomb?
back: A combined incendiary and explosive device developed by Jock Lewes specifically for destroying parked aircraft

front: What was the LRDG?
back: The Long Range Desert Group - a reconnaissance unit that transported SAS teams to their targets

front: When did David Stirling get captured?
back: January 27, 1943, in Tunisia. He spent the rest of the war in Colditz.

front: What was the German 88mm gun famous for?
back: Originally an anti-aircraft gun, Rommel adapted it as a devastating anti-tank weapon with long range and high velocity

front: What was the Matilda II?
back: A British 'infantry tank' with heavy armor but slow speed, effective against Italians but vulnerable to the 88mm

front: What was a Jerrycan?
back: The superior German fuel container design that the British and Americans eventually copied

front: What was Ultra?
back: The Allied intelligence program that broke German Enigma codes, revealing Axis supply problems and enabling convoy interception

front: What was the Desert Air Force?
back: The RAF command that provided air support to the Eighth Army, achieving air superiority by late 1942

front: When was Rommel promoted to Field Marshal?
back: June 21, 1942, after capturing Tobruk in a single day

front: What was Operation Crusader?
back: The British offensive in November-December 1941 that relieved the siege of Tobruk

front: What happened at Kasserine Pass?
back: Rommel inflicted a humiliating defeat on inexperienced American forces in February 1943

front: When did Rommel permanently leave North Africa?
back: March 9, 1943, sick and disillusioned, handing command to General von Arnim

front: What book did Rommel write about infantry tactics?
back: Infantry Attacks (Infanterie Greift An), published in 1937, based on his WWI experiences

front: How did the first SAS raid go?
back: It was a disaster - 55 men parachuted into a sandstorm, only 21 survived. But the unit was not disbanded.

front: How many aircraft did the SAS destroy at Tamet and Sirte?
back: 37 aircraft were destroyed on the ground on December 14, 1941

front: What was the M4 Sherman's main advantage?
back: It was reliable, easy to maintain, and produced in vast numbers, though not superior to German tanks individually

front: What was 'Hellfire Pass'?
back: The nickname for Halfaya Pass, due to the deadly German 88mm guns positioned there
